text.Prompt:
Computer networking giant Cisco will launch a five year Australian investment program valued at up to $31 million in a bid to increase the pool of talent available with skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. (STEM).

The main pillar of the investment, which will be officially announced on Tuesday, is a $21 million Australian training program for 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM related areas.

Pitched as a solution to the lag in science and technology innovation in Australia, Cisco's new five-year AUSTEM 2020 program, will accelerate its existing 16-year-old Networking Academy Program, by seeking to train young people at three times the current rate.

Ken Boal of Cisco says industry must do more to promote the study of science and technology. Justin McManus

The scheme will broaden curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs and secondary schools, by introducing subjects such as cyber security, cloud and the so-called "internet of things".

"We are the middle of the road for funding and international collaboration, middle of the road for performance in schools, and on science, maths and literacy. And middle of the road just isn't going to cut it if we want to get ahead and maintain our standard of living," said Cisco Australia and New Zealand vice-president and Commonwealth Science Council member, Ken Boal.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A:
Cisco, a giant in computer networking, has launched a five-year investment program in Australia worth up to $31 million to increase the pool of talent in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). This program, called AUSTEM 2020, will train 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM-related areas at three times the current rate, broadening curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs, and secondary schools to include cyber security, cloud computing, and the "internet of things."

Ken Boal, Cisco Australia and New Zealand vice-president and Commonwealth Science Council member, emphasizes the need for the industry to promote the study of science and technology to remain competitive and maintain the country's standard of living. With this program, Cisco aims to address the lag in science and technology innovation in Australia and prepare the next generation of professionals to meet the growing demand for STEM skills.

In summary, AUSTEM 2020 is a comprehensive program that will significantly increase the pool of STEM talent in Australia, providing students with relevant skills and knowledge to succeed in the ever-evolving technology landscape. By investing in this program, Cisco demonstrates its commitment to promoting science and technology education and innovation in Australia.
text.Response B: Cisco plans to invest up to $31 million over 5 years in Australia to increase the talent pool in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). The main pillar of the investment is a $21 million training program for 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM related areas. The program, called AUSTEM 2020, will accelerate Cisco's existing 16-year-old Networking Academy Program by training three times as many people. The program will broaden curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs and secondary schools to include subjects like cyber security, cloud computing and the "internet of things." Cisco believes industry must do more to promote the study of science and technology in Australia, which is lagging behind other countries in this area.

meta.preamble_a: Respond authoritatively, assertively and persuasively, as if you are very knowledgeable about the topic.
meta.preamble_b: Respond using complex language, long words and technical terms, as if you are an expert.

Prompt

Computer networking giant Cisco will launch a five year Australian investment program valued at up to $31 million in a bid to increase the pool of talent available with skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. (STEM).

The main pillar of the investment, which will be officially announced on Tuesday, is a $21 million Australian training program for 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM related areas.

Pitched as a solution to the lag in science and technology innovation in Australia, Cisco's new five-year AUSTEM 2020 program, will accelerate its existing 16-year-old Networking Academy Program, by seeking to train young people at three times the current rate.

Ken Boal of Cisco says industry must do more to promote the study of science and technology. Justin McManus

The scheme will broaden curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs and secondary schools, by introducing subjects such as cyber security, cloud and the so-called "internet of things".

"We are the middle of the road for funding and international collaboration, middle of the road for performance in schools, and on science, maths and literacy. And middle of the road just isn't going to cut it if we want to get ahead and maintain our standard of living," said Cisco Australia and New Zealand vice-president and Commonwealth Science Council member, Ken Boal.

Response A

Cisco, a giant in computer networking, has launched a five-year investment program in Australia worth up to $31 million to increase the pool of talent in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). This program, called AUSTEM 2020, will train 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM-related areas at three times the current rate, broadening curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs, and secondary schools to include cyber security, cloud computing, and the "internet of things."

Ken Boal, Cisco Australia and New Zealand vice-president and Commonwealth Science Council member, emphasizes the need for the industry to promote the study of science and technology to remain competitive and maintain the country's standard of living. With this program, Cisco aims to address the lag in science and technology innovation in Australia and prepare the next generation of professionals to meet the growing demand for STEM skills.

In summary, AUSTEM 2020 is a comprehensive program that will significantly increase the pool of STEM talent in Australia, providing students with relevant skills and knowledge to succeed in the ever-evolving technology landscape. By investing in this program, Cisco demonstrates its commitment to promoting science and technology education and innovation in Australia.

Response B

Cisco plans to invest up to $31 million over 5 years in Australia to increase the talent pool in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). The main pillar of the investment is a $21 million training program for 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM related areas. The program, called AUSTEM 2020, will accelerate Cisco's existing 16-year-old Networking Academy Program by training three times as many people. The program will broaden curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs and secondary schools to include subjects like cyber security, cloud computing and the "internet of things." Cisco believes industry must do more to promote the study of science and technology in Australia, which is lagging behind other countries in this area.
